value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">32</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or the rain pours have some strong inducement; something</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that puzzles; and then concludes. They must have love;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">murder; adultery. And this 
            <choice>
              <sic>contrbution</sic>
              <corr>contribution</corr>
            </choice> of the audience</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was more unfortunate to the dramatist 
            <choice>
              <sic>tahn</sic>
              <corr>than</corr>
            </choice> to the lyric</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">singer. Often the actions is too violent for the words.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There is a dislocation between the thought and the action.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">No one feels what is said. The emotion is often</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>las ered</sic>
              <corr>plastered</corr>
            </choice> on to a dumb figure. But if violence rapidity</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">movement are dictated by the audience an inevitable 
            <choice>
              <sic>confusin</sic>
              <corr>confusion</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">follows. On the other hand the playwright</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">like the singer has an anomymous vitality,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">drawn 
            <choice>
              <sic>fro</sic>
              <corr>from</corr>
            </choice> other bodies, a 
            <choice>
              <sic>pe renniel</sic>
              <corr>perennial</corr>
            </choice> common vigour.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Nor is <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">anon</rs> 
            <choice>
              <sic>dad</sic>
              <corr>dead</corr>
            </choice> in ourselves. The crude early 
            <choice>
              <sic>ddrams</sic>
              <corr>dramas</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have still the power to make us ask--as the audience asked--</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the childs 
            <choice>
              <sic>questin</sic>
              <corr>question</corr>
            </choice>: what comes next? <add hand="ms" place="inline">a power denied to [20th?] century [illeg.]</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">So we become 
            <choice>
              <sic>ourelves</sic>
              <corr>ourselves</corr>
            </choice> anonymous in the early plays.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is only later when the pressure of silent 
            <choice>
              <sic>horaded</sic>
              <corr>hoarded</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">emotion had thrown up words, as the 
            <choice>
              <sic>fi gers</sic>
              <corr>fingers</corr>
            </choice> of the man at the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="object" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#obj-mono" key="Monotype">monotype machine</rs> casts letters from the bubbling lead,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that we lose this general quality to gain---</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">everything it seems. For the 
            <choice>
              <sic>curatin</sic>
              <corr>curtain</corr>
            </choice> goes on rising</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">incessantly for fifty years. Now it rises on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-hen5" key="Henry V">Henry the Fifth</rs>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">then on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-mids" key="Midsummer Night's Dream, A">Midsummer Nights Dream</rs>; on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-rome" key="Romeo and Juliet">Romeo and Juliet</rs>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-haml" key="Hamlet">Hamlet</rs>; finally on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-temp" key="Tempest, The">the Tempest</rs>. 
            <choice>
              <sic>Byt</sic>
              <corr>By</corr>
            </choice> that time the sxxgxx</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">play has outgrown the stage. The stage has become too small</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to act this drama. Perhaps after 
            <choice>
              <sic>cnuries</sic>
              <corr>centuries</corr>
            </choice>, the play will</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">come to birth again, differently, in <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-magi" key="Magic Flute, The">the Magic Flute</rs>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-fide" key="Fidelio">Fidelio</rs>. But the play never again fitted the stage</l>
